is a small riverside village in
wedged in between karst mountains at the confluence of the Nam Ngoi and the Nam Ou rivers. In the last few years it is beginning to appear as a destination on the
as a backpacker favorite. Nevertheless, it remains a low-key destination in a stunning location. Interesting hikes can be made to tribal villages in the area.
2 minivans per day from Luang Prabang to
(3.5 hours, 09:00, 10:30) Take the connecting 1-hour boatride from
(daily, 11:00 and 14:00, 25,000 kip) or, if you're coming from the north, grab the 5-hour boat from

value: name=Tham Kang Cave and Tham Pha Kaew Cave
directions=From the main street, take the second street left, cross the wooden bridge and soccer field and continue straight

content=These caves were bomb shelters during the Vietnam War. North of town, about 50 min by foot and can be found without a guide. Continue past the caves for about 45 min to reach Ban Na village for lunch.
content=At the end of the dry season when the water is low, take a cool splash in the Nam Ou or sip from a cocktail on a bamboo chaise longue.
content=Change your old books for new ones at this 2 for 1 book exchange with more than 300 titles.
alt=Bana, Huay Bo, and Huay Sen

directions=To Bana, walk ~30 min past Tham Kang Cave. It's on the left side across the rice fields. To Huay Bo, you'll need to walk another 20 min past Bana by crossing the river. To Huay Bo, follow the sign to Konsavan Guesthouse that'll lead you across the river
content=There are guest houses in all 3 villages, costing 5,000-15,000 kip for a bungalow.
directions=Halfway down the main street on the right
content=Good Lao food and cold Beerlao. Makes its own bread and pizza dough.
directions=Immediately left of the boat landing
content=Solid and clean. Boasts big wooden balcony and marble table seats on the grass.
directions=At the far part of the main street, look for the black sign on the left side..
directions=In the middle of the main road on the right-hand side
content=Nicksa's Place has 2 restaurants, 50 m away from each other on the main road. The furthest one offers good prices and a very quiet view on the river.
directions=Left of the boat landing stairs take the path passing the boat office
content=Big open-air terrace overlooking the Nam Ou. Best view in town.
content=Best all-you-can-eat breakfast buffet in town. First house on the main street with a stone step.
directions=On the left when arriving by boat at the edge of the village
content=Charming bamboo bar nestled under two big intertwined trees, overlooking the Nam Ou. Great spot in high season with fireplace on the beach.
content=Nice spot completely at the long end of the main road on the left. Bar with stools, couches and fireplace. Great Italian red wine.

Muang Ngoi Neua, Luang Prabang 
Province
directions=On the main street as well as close to the river
content=Upmarket choice. Hardwood bungalows with en suite bath, nice garden and good restaurant.
directions=Halfway down main road, on the right
content=Riverside bungalows with attached bath, and two hammocks for each bungalow. Friendly staff. Seems to be one of the best budget options.
content=Clean wooden bungalows overlooking the Nam Ou.
directions=Far left of the boat dock
content=Bungalows with private bath, comfy beds, and superb view over the river. Has a big book collection in the guesthouse on the main street.
content=3-storey concrete building with restaurant overlooking the river, close to the boat steps, tallest building in town.
directions=Look for the sign on the main street half way through on the left
content=Private bungalows with hammock in a hidden away spot deep inside the village. Great outdoor seating with bar & restaurant.

Bring boots/old shoes if you arrive in rainy season, as roads are unpaved and can get muddy.
(daily, 09:30, 25,000 kip) to continue to Luang Prabang or charter a boat to Muang Khua for connections to
and Vietnam. It is also possible to make a one day hike or kayak trip back to Nong Khiaw.
